Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3709775 d 1 Introduction e In predicting stock return comovements, research has focused on the leverage effect, being the w empirical evidence that stock prices correlate more during market downturns than upturns (Ang &Chen,2002). Inadditiontotheseasymmetries,theacademicliteraturehasdocumentedseveral e other stylized facts about the correlation between stock returns. Two broad theories regarding return comovements have been analyzed (Barberis, Shleifer, & Wurgiler, 2005). The traditional v theory assumes that the market is frictionless and states that stock price correlations reflect the e correlations in fundamental values. In contrast, sentiment-based theories assumes that market frictionsexistandthatstockpricecomovementsareattributedtoinvestors’behaviorratherthan r to the comovement in fundamental values. Investors have been found, for instance, to simplify investment decisions by grouping stocks into categorries (Barberis & Shleifer, 2003). Changes in e their aggregated sentiment induce comovements in the return of stocks belonging to the same category (Kumar & Lee, 2006). Drake, Jennings, Roulstone, and Thornock (2017) and Huang, e Huang, and Lin (2019) attribute non-fundamental comovement in stock prices to changes in p investors’ attention. Their findings show that when investors pay more attention to market-level information rather than firm-specifi c news, stock returns correlate more. t While there is considerable empirical evidence on the factors influencing stock price comove- o ments, their (out-of-sample) predictive power for return covariances, excluding the leverage effect, has received littlne attention. Although the predictive content of retail investors’ trading behavior has been documented for stock return volatility (see, e.g., Audrino, Sigrist, & Balli- nari, 2020), its forecasting power for correlations has not yet been analyzed. Numerous studies t have proposednextensions of classical multivariate volatility models to account for asymmetries in volatilities and correlations (see, among others, Bollerslev, Patton, & Quaedvlieg, 2020; Cap- i piello,Enrgle,&Sheppard,2006;deGoeij&Marquering,2004;Francq&Zakoïan,2012;McAleer, p Hoti, & Chan, 2009). However, only a few models have been developed that allow exogenous variables to influence the prediction of the returns’ covariance matrix (e.g. Audrino & Corsi, e 2010; Audrino & Trojani, 2011; Bauer & Vorkink, 2011). There are two potential reasons for the r lack of studies that analyze the predictive power of sentiment-based theories of price comove- P ment: (i) these stylized facts do not have out-of-sample predictive power for the comovement of stock returns, or (ii) the literature lacks a suitable model to analyze their forecasting ability. 1 This preprint research paper has not been peer reviewed. First, we introduce a new e model of realized correlations, allowing exogenous predictors to have a non-linear influence on the model’s forecasts. Building on the model of Audrino and Trojani (2011)w, we propose a tree- structured version of the realized covariance HAR-DRD model of Oh and Patton (2016). Thvis approach allows exogenous predictors to directly influence the model’s parameters by ensuring the predicted covariance e matrix’s positive definiteness.
